key_work.title: Edwin S Porter
key_work.brief_description: Edwin S Porter pushed the boundaries of film editing and was central to developing the new screen language. He created gradual transitions and dissolves between scenes and perfected cross-cutting to show simultaneous action.

links.description: The final scene of The Great Train Robbery directly influenced the famous ‘gun-barrel’ openings of the James Bond films, beginning with Dr. No in 1962. The gun-barrel openings break the fourth wall and place the viewer in the perspective of a would-be assassin.

end.title: GoldenEye 007
end.brief_description: GoldenEye 007 inspired endless fun when it was released on the Nintendo 64 – just as long as you didn’t look at anyone’s screen or play as Odd Job. One of the first multi-player first-person-shooters for console, GoldenEye made everyone 007.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_other.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

recommendations.quote: There's never been a better adaptation of film into a videogame than Golden Eye. For the first time, up to four players could shoot it out on one TV screen and take control of one of some of cinema's best heroes and villains. And yes, Odd Job is cheating.

links.description: While viewers were placed in the perspective of someone aiming at Bond in the gun-barrel openings, the videogame GoldenEye put players in the perspective of Bond himself.
